entries.meaning: A conduit made of pipes used to convey water, gas or petroleum etc.
examples: An oil pipeline has been opened from the Caspian Sea.

entries.meaning: A channel (either physical or logical) by which information is transmitted sequentially (that is, the first information in is the first information out).
examples: 3D images are rendered using the graphics pipeline.

entries.meaning: (figurative) A system or process through which something is conducted.
examples: A new version of the software is in the pipeline, but has not been rolled out.

entries.meaning: (surfing) The inside of a wave that a surfer is riding, when the wave has started closing over it.

verbs.description: pipeline (third-person singular simple present pipelines, present participle pipelining, simple past and past participle pipelined)

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive) To design (a microchip etc.) so that processing takes place in efficient stages, the output of each stage being fed as input to the next.
(transitive) To convey something by a system of pipes
(transitive) To lay a system of pipes through something
(rare, slang, transitive) To connect a tube from ones mouth to ones anus (or the anus of another), in order to force someone to eat feces.
